articles.content:
A political ideology is a set of principles aimed at establishing or
maintaining a certain social system; it is a program of long-range action, with
the principles serving to unify and integrate particular steps into a
consistent course. It is only by means of principles that men can project the
future and choose their actions accordingly.
articles.attribution:
“The Wreckage of the Consensus,”
Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal, 222

articles.content:
A majority without an ideology is a helpless mob, to be taken over by anyone . . . .
Political freedom requires much more than the people’s wish. It requires
an enormously complex knowledge of political theory and of how to implement it
in practice.
articles.attribution:
“Theory and Practice,”
Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal, 138
